query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Al fine de le sue parole il ladro 2 le mani alzò con amendue le fiche, 3 gridando: «Togli, Dio, ch’a te le squadro!».
query.result: 1 At the end of his words the thief 2 the hands he raised with both the fiches, 3 shouting: “Take away, God, that to you I tear them!”

4 From then on here the friendly serpents were to me, 5 because one of them wrapped herself then about the neck, 6 as if she said ‘I do not want that she say more’;
7 and another to the arms, and I rolled it again, 8 reaffirming herself before, 9 that she could not with them give a collapse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Ahi Pistoia, Pistoia, ché non stanzi 11 d’incenerarti sì che più non duri, 12 poi che ’n mal fare il seme tuo avanzi?
13 Per tutt’ i cerchi de lo ’nferno scuri 14 non vidi spirto in Dio tanto superbo, 15 non quel che cadde a Tebe giù da’ muri.
query.result:
10 Ah Pistoia, Pistoia, that you do not stay 11 to incinerate you so that it no longer endures, 12 then that in evil deeds your seed advances?
13 Through all the circles of the dark hell 14 I did not see spirit in God so proud, 15 not that which fell in Thebes down from the walls.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
16 El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo; 17 e io vidi un centauro pien di rabbia 18 venir chiamando: «Ov’ è, ov’ è l’acerbo?».

Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Maremma non cred’ io che tante n’abbia, 20 quante bisce elli avea su per la groppa 21 infin ove comincia nostra labbia.
query.result: 19 Maremma I do not believe that it has so many, 20 as many snakes he had up on the back, 21 as far as where our lip begins.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Sovra le spalle, dietro da la coppa, 23 con l’ali aperte li giacea un draco; 24 e quello affuoca qualunque s’intoppa.

Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Lo mio maestro disse: «Questi è Caco, 26 che, sotto ’l sasso di monte Aventino, 27 di sangue fece spesse volte laco.
query.result: 25 My master said: “This is Caco, 26 who, under the stone of Mount Aventine, 27 of blood made many times a wound.

28 He does not go with his brothers on a road, 29 because of the theft that he deceitfully made 30 of the great herd that he had nearby;
31 where his works cease, drunk 32 under the mace of Hercules, which perhaps 33 gave him a hundred, and did not hear the ten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse, 35 e tre spiriti venner sotto noi, 36 de’ quai né io né ’l duca mio s’accorse,
37 se non quando gridar: «Chi siete voi?»; 38 per che nostra novella si ristette, 39 e intendemmo pur ad essi poi.
query.result:
34 While he was speaking thus, and he passed, 35 and three spirits came beneath us, 36 of which neither I nor my duke noticed,
37 except when (he) shouted: “Who are you?”; 38 for which our story was retold, 39 and we understood them also thereafter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Io non li conoscea; ma ei seguette, 41 come suol seguitar per alcun caso, 42 che l’un nomar un altro convenette,
43 dicendo: «Cianfa dove fia rimaso?»; 44 per ch’io, acciò che ’l duca stesse attento, 45 mi puosi ’l dito su dal mento al naso.
query.result:
40 I did not know them; but I followed him, 41 as one usually follows for some case, 42 that to name one another was fitting,
43 saying: “Cianfa where will it be left?”; 44 so that I, lest the duke remain attentive, 45 I placed my finger on the chin to the nose.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 Se tu se’ or, lettore, a creder lento 47 ciò ch’io dirò, non sarà maraviglia, 48 ché io che ’l vidi, a pena il mi consento.
query.result: 46 If you are now, reader, slow to believe 47 that which I shall say will not be a marvel, 48 for I who saw it, barely consent it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Com’ io tenea levate in lor le ciglia, 50 e un serpente con sei piè si lancia 51 dinanzi a l’uno, e tutto a lui s’appiglia.
query.result: 49 As I held lifted in them the eyelashes, 50 and a serpent with six feet throws itself, 51 in front of the one, and everything clings to him.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue 59 ad alber sì, come l’orribil fiera 60 per l’altrui membra avviticchiò le sue.
query.result: 58 Ellera was never ever clothed 59 to a tree thus, like the horrible beast 60 through the other's limbs she twisted her own.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Poi s’appiccar, come di calda cera 62 fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore, 63 né l’un né l’altro già parea quel ch’era:
64 come procede innanzi da l’ardore, 65 per lo papiro suso, un color bruno 66 che non è nero ancora e ’l bianco more.
query.result:
61 Then they stick together, like hot wax 62 they had been, and mix their colour, 63 neither one nor the other already seemed what it was:
64 as it proceeds forward from the heat, 65 through the papyrus upward, a brown colour 66 that is not yet black and the white dies.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 Li altri due ’l riguardavano, e ciascuno 68 gridava: «Omè, Agnel, come ti muti! 69 Vedi che già non se’ né due né uno».
query.result: 67 The other two were looking at him, and each 68 shouted: “Alas, Agnel, how you become mute! 69 See that already you are neither two nor one.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Già eran li due capi un divenuti, 71 quando n’apparver due figure miste 72 in una faccia, ov’ eran due perduti.
query.result: 70 Already were the two heads one become, 71 when two mixed figures appeared of it 72 in one face, where two were lost.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste; 74 le cosce con le gambe e ’l ventre e ’l casso 75 divenner membra che non fuor mai viste.

Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso: 77 due e nessun l’imagine perversa 78 parea; e tal sen gio con lento passo.
query.result: 76 Every primary aspect there was broken: 77 two and none its perverse image 78 seemed; and such feeling with slow step.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Come ’l ramarro sotto la gran fersa 80 dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe, 81 folgore par se la via attraversa,
82 sì pareva, venendo verso l’epe 83 de li altri due, un serpentello acceso, 84 livido e nero come gran di pepe;
85 e quella parte onde prima è preso 86 nostro alimento, a l’un di lor trafisse; 87 poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso.

Please translate each line literally into English.
88 Lo trafitto ’l mirò, ma nulla disse; 89 anzi, co’ piè fermati, sbadigliava 90 pur come sonno o febbre l’assalisse.

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Elli ’l serpente e quei lui riguardava; 92 l’un per la piaga e l’altro per la bocca 93 fummavan forte, e ’l fummo si scontrava.

Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Taccia Lucano ormai là dov’ e’ tocca 95 del misero Sabello e di Nasidio, 96 e attenda a udir quel ch’or si scocca.
query.result: 94 Taccia Lucano now there where it touches 95 of the wretched Sabello and of Nasidio, 96 and wait to hear what now is launched.

97 Silence of Cadmus and of Arethusa Ovid, 98 because if that one in serpent and that one in spring 99 converts poetizing, I do not envy it;
100 because two natures never face to face 101 did not transmute so that amendue the forms 102 to change their matter would be ready.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme, 104 che ’l serpente la coda in forca fesse, 105 e ’l feruto ristrinse insieme l’orme.
query.result: 103 Together they responded to those norms, 104 that the serpent cut the tail in a fork, 105 and the wounded re‑took together the limbs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse 107 s’appiccar sì, che ’n poco la giuntura 108 non facea segno alcun che si paresse.
query.result: 106 The legs with the thighs themselves dry 107 stuck together so, that in a short [time] the joint 108 made no sign at all that it seemed

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Togliea la coda fessa la figura 110 che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle 111 si facea molle, e quella di là dura.
query.result: 109 It removed the broken tail the figure 110 that was disappearing there, and its skin 111 was becoming soft, and that one over there hard.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Io vidi intrar le braccia per l’ascelle, 113 e i due piè de la fiera, ch’eran corti, 114 tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle.
query.result: 112 I saw go into the arms through the armpits, 113 and the two feet of the beast, which were short, 114 as much to lengthen as they shortened those.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti, 116 diventaron lo membro che l’uom cela, 117 e ’l misero del suo n’avea due porti.
query.result: 115 Afterwards the hind feet, together twisted, 116 became the member that the man hides, 117 and the wretched of his n' had two ports.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Mentre che ’l fummo l’uno e l’altro vela 119 di color novo, e genera ’l pel suso 120 per l’una parte e da l’altra il dipela,
121 l’un si levò e l’altro cadde giuso, 122 non torcendo però le lucerne empie, 123 sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso.
query.result:
118 While the smoke veils the one and the other 119 of new color, and generates the skin upward 120 on one side and from the other it undresses it,
121 the one rose and the other fell down, 122 not twisting however the full lanterns, 123 under which each one changed its face.

124 He who was straight, drew toward the temples, 125 and of too much mud that came there, 126 the ears of the broken cheeks went out;
127 that which did not run backward and held itself, 128 of that excess, made a nose on the face, 129 and the lips enlarged as much as was fitting.

130 That which lay, the muzzle forward drives, 131 and the ears withdraw through the head 132 as the horns the lumaccia made;
133 and the tongue, which had united and ready 134 first to speak, it splits, and the forced 135 in the other it closes again; and the smoke remains.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 L’anima ch’era fiera divenuta, 137 suffolando si fugge per la valle, 138 e l’altro dietro a lui parlando sputa.
query.result: 136 The soul that was fierce became, 137 blowing it flees through the valley, 138 and the other behind him, speaking, spits.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Poscia li volse le novelle spalle, 140 e disse a l’altro: «I’ vo’ che Buoso corra, 141 com’ ho fatt’ io, carpon per questo calle».
query.result: 139 Afterwards he turned them, the new shoulders, 140 and said to the other: “I want Buoso to run, 141 as I have done, I seize for this street.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
142 Così vid’ io la settima zavorra 143 mutare e trasmutare; e qui mi scusi 144 la novità se fior la penna abborra.
query.result: 142 Thus I saw the seventh ballast 143 to change and transmute; and here excuse me 144 the novelty if it blooms the pen abhors

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
145 E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi 146 fossero alquanto e l’animo smagato, 147 non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,
148 ch’i’ non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato; 149 ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni 150 che venner prima, non era mutato;
151 l’altr’ era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni.
